description: Transforms a signal from time domain to frequency domain. In pvx workflows this directly affects spectral resolution, leakage behavior, and overlap-add reconstruction accuracy in STFT-based processing.
Efficient algorithm for computing the discrete Fourier transform. Its computational efficiency is critical because pvx repeatedly computes FFTs frame-by-frame across channels and files.
Inverse operation that reconstructs time-domain samples from spectral bins. Accurate inverse transforms are required to reconstruct low-artifact audio after spectral-domain edits.
Tapering function applied before spectral analysis to control leakage. Window shape selection is one of the strongest controls on sidelobe suppression versus main-lobe width.
Raised cosine window commonly used in STFT analysis. It is a common default because it offers a strong practical balance between leakage control and frequency resolution.
Cosine-sum window with reduced nearest sidelobe amplitude. Compared with Hann it slightly reduces nearest sidelobes, often at the cost of different amplitude bias characteristics.
Cosine-sum window with stronger sidelobe suppression. In pvx workflows this directly affects spectral resolution, leakage behavior, and overlap-add reconstruction accuracy in STFT-based processing.
Parametric window controlled by beta parameter. The beta parameter gives explicit control over the width-versus-sidelobe tradeoff, which is useful for task-specific tuning.

Energy spread across bins due to finite-duration analysis windows. In pvx workflows this directly affects spectral resolution, leakage behavior, and overlap-add reconstruction accuracy in STFT-based processing.
Frequency-domain folding caused by undersampling. Unchecked aliasing folds out-of-band content back into the audible band, often creating false partials or metallic artifacts.

Half the sample rate; highest representable frequency in sampled audio. In pvx workflows this directly affects spectral resolution, leakage behavior, and overlap-add reconstruction accuracy in STFT-based processing.

Frame-based reconstruction by summing overlapped windowed segments. In pvx workflows this directly affects spectral resolution, leakage behavior, and overlap-add reconstruction accuracy in STFT-based processing.

Linear filtering operation in time domain equivalent to multiplication in frequency domain. In pvx workflows this directly affects spectral resolution, leakage behavior, and overlap-add reconstruction accuracy in STFT-based processing.

Filter phase response that preserves waveform shape of band-limited signals. In pvx workflows this directly affects spectral resolution, leakage behavior, and overlap-add reconstruction accuracy in STFT-based processing.

System with minimum group delay for a given magnitude response. In pvx workflows this directly affects spectral resolution, leakage behavior, and overlap-add reconstruction accuracy in STFT-based processing.
STFT-based time-scale/pitch framework using phase propagation. It underpins most pvx core transforms by decoupling time-scale and pitch behavior through phase-consistent spectral resynthesis.
Strategies that protect attacks during spectral time modification. Without transient-aware handling, attacks can smear, so this is central for drums and articulation-critical material.
Locking neighboring bin phases to preserve local waveform structure. Locking strategies reduce local phase incoherence, improving clarity and reducing chorus-like blur in stretched material.
Phase-locking variant that follows dominant peaks. In pvx this concept determines how frames are aligned, phases are propagated, and transients are preserved during time-stretch and pitch operations.
Waveform-similarity overlap-add time-scale modification. It is often preferred for moderate speech/music time changes when waveform continuity is more important than heavy spectral editing.
Time-domain pitch-synchronous overlap-add technique. It is effective for voiced monophonic content where pitch periods are trackable and edits should remain time-domain natural.
Linear-prediction-assisted PSOLA variant. Linear-prediction support can improve source/filter control and reduce timbral drift in speech-like material.
Harmonic-percussive source separation in TF domain. Harmonic and percussive components can then be processed with different settings to preserve punch while shaping sustain.
Sound synthesis/modification using short grains. In pvx this concept determines how frames are aligned, phases are propagated, and transients are preserved during time-stretch and pitch operations.
Piecewise mapping from output time to input time. In pvx this concept determines how frames are aligned, phases are propagated, and transients are preserved during time-stretch and pitch operations.
Preservation of spectral envelope while pitch is changed. This helps avoid chipmunk/monster timbre artifacts when pitch is shifted significantly.
Fundamental-frequency estimator using difference-function minima. It is commonly used as a robust baseline detector for monophonic F0 tracks.
Probabilistic extension of YIN with voicing model. Its probabilistic voicing model can improve contour stability relative to raw framewise estimates.
Robust algorithm for pitch tracking. In pvx retune pipelines this governs pitch-target decisions, microtonal mapping behavior, and the stability of note-to-note correction.
Sawtooth-waveform inspired pitch estimator. It emphasizes sawtooth-like harmonic structure, which can improve robustness on certain voiced spectra.
Downsample-and-multiply spectrum for F0 evidence. In pvx retune pipelines this governs pitch-target decisions, microtonal mapping behavior, and the stability of note-to-note correction.
Weighted subharmonic summation for F0 estimation. In pvx retune pipelines this governs pitch-target decisions, microtonal mapping behavior, and the stability of note-to-note correction.
Logarithmic pitch interval unit (1200 cents per octave). Because cents are logarithmic, fixed cent offsets represent musically consistent relative pitch intervals anywhere in the register.
Tuning system dividing octave into equal semitone ratios. It is the default modern tuning grid but may be intentionally replaced for historical or microtonal work.
Tuning based on low-integer frequency ratios. Its pure-ratio intervals can sound more consonant in context but depend strongly on key and harmonic function.
Text format for microtonal scales. Using Scala files allows precise import of non-12TET interval maps into repeatable production workflows.
Specification for non-12TET tuning in MIDI systems. This enables compatible systems to exchange alternate tunings without redefining note identities.
Continuous slide between notes. Retune systems often need slide-aware logic so expressive glides are not flattened into abrupt quantized jumps.
Transform with logarithmic center frequencies and constant Q. Its logarithmic spacing is especially useful for music analysis where pitch perception is logarithmic.
Generalized CQT with variable Q and bandwidth behavior. Compared to CQT, VQT broadens control over Q and bandwidth behavior across frequency ranges.
Nonstationary Gabor transform with invertible adaptive filter banks. NSGT offers adaptive, invertible filter-bank behavior beyond fixed-resolution STFT framing.
Sharper TF representation by moving energy to local centroids. Reassignment can sharpen time-frequency energy localization for clearer ridge and onset interpretation.
Post-processing that concentrates TF energy along ridges. It can concentrate ridge energy for improved instantaneous-frequency interpretation.
Transform using chirped atoms. In pvx transform modules this shapes the tradeoff between time localization, frequency precision, and invertibility of analysis/resynthesis steps.
Hierarchical wavelet decomposition of both low/high branches. It supports multi-band decomposition where both approximation and detail branches are recursively analyzed.

Nested subspace structure for multi-scale representations. In pvx transform modules this shapes the tradeoff between time localization, frequency precision, and invertibility of analysis/resynthesis steps.
Nonnegative factorization of matrices into parts-based components. Factor count and constraints strongly influence whether components are musically meaningful or overly fragmented.

Blind source separation based on statistical independence. In pvx decomposition workflows this assumption controls source isolation quality, bleed rejection, and the interpretability of separated components.
Low-rank + sparse decomposition robust to outliers. It is frequently used to separate stable backgrounds from sparse foreground events.
Higher-order extension of matrix factorization. In pvx decomposition workflows this assumption controls source isolation quality, bleed rejection, and the interpretability of separated components.
Canonical polyadic tensor decomposition. In pvx decomposition workflows this assumption controls source isolation quality, bleed rejection, and the interpretability of separated components.
Core tensor with mode matrices factorization. In pvx decomposition workflows this assumption controls source isolation quality, bleed rejection, and the interpretability of separated components.
Encoder-decoder CNN with skip connections. In pvx decomposition workflows this assumption controls source isolation quality, bleed rejection, and the interpretability of separated components.
Deep waveform-domain music source separation architecture. Neural stem separation quality can be high, but behavior depends heavily on training-domain match.
MMSE linear estimator for noisy observations. It is a classic linear MMSE approach and still valuable as a reliable baseline enhancer.
Subtracts estimated noise spectrum from noisy signal. In pvx restoration chains this controls denoise or dereverb strength versus artifact risk, helping balance intelligibility and texture retention.
MMSE short-time spectral amplitude estimator. It estimates clean spectral amplitudes from noisy observations while minimizing expected short-time error.
Log-spectral MMSE enhancement estimator. Its log-domain objective often better tracks perceptual sensitivity than raw-amplitude objectives.

Noise tracking from low percentile/minimum spectral statistics. In pvx restoration chains this controls denoise or dereverb strength versus artifact risk, helping balance intelligibility and texture retention.
Hybrid recurrent neural + DSP speech denoiser. In pvx restoration chains this controls denoise or dereverb strength versus artifact risk, helping balance intelligibility and texture retention.

Generative model based on iterative denoising processes. In pvx restoration chains this controls denoise or dereverb strength versus artifact risk, helping balance intelligibility and texture retention.
Reconstruction of clipped waveform segments. In pvx restoration chains this controls denoise or dereverb strength versus artifact risk, helping balance intelligibility and texture retention.
Removal of impulsive click artifacts. In pvx restoration chains this controls denoise or dereverb strength versus artifact risk, helping balance intelligibility and texture retention.
Suppression of late reverberation components. In pvx restoration chains this controls denoise or dereverb strength versus artifact risk, helping balance intelligibility and texture retention.
Multi-channel dereverb by delayed linear prediction. WPE is a standard dereverberation baseline for suppressing late reverberant tails in multichannel settings.
Joint estimation of source and room/filter response. In pvx restoration chains this controls denoise or dereverb strength versus artifact risk, helping balance intelligibility and texture retention.
Ratio of direct sound energy to reverberant energy. In pvx restoration chains this controls denoise or dereverb strength versus artifact risk, helping balance intelligibility and texture retention.
Dynamic range processor that reduces gain above threshold. Threshold, ratio, attack, and release jointly define how quickly and how strongly level is controlled.
Dynamic processor that reduces gain below threshold. It can reduce low-level noise floors and room tail audibility by attenuating content below threshold.
Combined compressor and expander behavior. In pvx mastering stages this affects loudness compliance, peak containment, and perceived punch versus transparency across final renders.
High-ratio compressor preventing peaks from exceeding threshold. In mastering chains it is commonly the final safety stage to prevent over-level peaks.
Peak estimate including inter-sample overs. True-peak metering estimates inter-sample peaks that sample-peak meters can miss.
Loudness unit relative to full scale. Targeting LUFS helps keep perceived program loudness consistent across tracks and delivery contexts.
International loudness measurement recommendation. Its weighting and gating model is the industry baseline for objective integrated loudness measurement.
European loudness standard for production and broadcast. R128 operationalizes BS.1770 loudness measurement into practical broadcast and production targets.
Abrupt saturation by truncating waveform beyond threshold. In pvx mastering stages this affects loudness compliance, peak containment, and perceived punch versus transparency across final renders.
Smooth saturation curve reducing harsh distortion. In pvx mastering stages this affects loudness compliance, peak containment, and perceived punch versus transparency across final renders.
Combining spectral magnitude and phase or envelopes across signals. Different choices of magnitude/phase or envelope transfer produce very different timbral identities.
Holding a short-time spectrum and resynthesizing over time. Freeze methods hold a selected spectral snapshot and are useful for drones, pads, and transitions.
Resonance region of spectral envelope. In pvx creative processing this primarily controls intentional timbral coloration and motion, not transparent corrective behavior.
Filter structure emphasizing a narrow band. In pvx creative processing this primarily controls intentional timbral coloration and motion, not transparent corrective behavior.
Multiplication by a carrier to produce sidebands. Sideband generation can create inharmonic or bell-like textures depending on carrier/modulator relationships.
Modulating signal amplitude by a control waveform. In pvx creative processing this primarily controls intentional timbral coloration and motion, not transparent corrective behavior.
Modulating oscillator frequency by another signal. In pvx creative processing this primarily controls intentional timbral coloration and motion, not transparent corrective behavior.
Low-frequency oscillator used for modulation. In pvx creative processing this primarily controls intentional timbral coloration and motion, not transparent corrective behavior.
Spatial filtering using multiple microphones/loudspeakers. Array geometry and steering parameters dominate directivity and noise/interference suppression behavior.
Align-and-average array beamformer. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.
Minimum variance distortionless response beamforming. MVDR minimizes output power while preserving a desired look direction, improving interference rejection.
Adaptive beamforming with blocking matrix branch. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.

Beamforming with sharpened directivity often with regularization. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.
Estimated source direction from array measurements. DoA estimates are often the control signal for adaptive steering, tracking, or scene-aware processing.

Time-delay estimation using phase transform weighting. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.
3D audio representation using spherical harmonics. Ambisonic domains allow scene rotation and format conversion before final speaker/headphone decoding.
4-channel WXYZ ambisonic format. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.

Ambisonics beyond first order for higher spatial resolution. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.
Headphone rendering preserving spatial localization cues. HRTF quality and listener assumptions strongly affect externalization and localization realism.

Head-related transfer function per source direction. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.
Arrival-time difference cue for localization. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.
Level difference cue for localization. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.
Vector-base amplitude panning for loudspeaker arrays. VBAP is widely used for loudspeaker panning with controllable phantom-image placement.
Distance-based amplitude panning. DBAP generalizes panning by amplitude weighting from geometric distance rather than simplex triplets.

Stereo representation as sum (mid) and difference (side). In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.

Loudspeaker technique reducing opposite-ear leakage. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.

Sound field with many uncorrelated incoming directions. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.
Acoustic response from source impulse to receiver. In pvx multichannel workflows this directly influences localization cues, interchannel coherence, and translation to speaker or headphone playback.
Detection of transient musical events. In pvx analysis and automation tools this determines feature reliability and how confidently metrics can drive downstream decisions.
Estimating temporal pulse positions from audio. In pvx analysis and automation tools this determines feature reliability and how confidently metrics can drive downstream decisions.
Inferring harmonic labels from tonal features. In pvx analysis and automation tools this determines feature reliability and how confidently metrics can drive downstream decisions.
Dividing music into sections like verse/chorus. In pvx analysis and automation tools this determines feature reliability and how confidently metrics can drive downstream decisions.
Global optimization of expensive objective functions. It is useful when parameter spaces are expensive to evaluate and objective surfaces are noisy.
Perceptual Evaluation of Speech Quality metric. PESQ is speech-focused and should be interpreted alongside task context and listening tests.
Short-Time Objective Intelligibility measure. STOI is an intelligibility-oriented metric and does not fully capture timbral preference.
Virtual Speech Quality Objective Listener metric family. ViSQOL provides perceptual similarity estimates and is often used with complementary quality metrics.
